author: R Sujatha
text:
A group of HIV positive persons from Karur has petitioned Chief Minister Jayalalithaa alleging that the Tamil Nadu State AIDS Control Society (TANSACS) was seeking to profile them by forcing them to submit their fingerprints.

In their petition, they said, “TANSACS had deployed some persons at anti-retroviral therapy centres in Karur to take our fingerprints. We have been given written instructions to bring all members of our families living with HIV and submit their fingerprints. We were also told to bring five members from our family and get their fingerprints registered.”

This, they said, was an invasion on their privacy and breach of confidentiality when the law has made it clear that HIV positive persons need not declare their status. The HIV positive persons said they were being profiled as they were receiving medicines free of cost.

However, Karur district HIV Positive Persons Network president K. Viswanathan said the aim of the programme was to weed out duplication of addresses. “In some cases, a recipient’s name and details has been entered twice. Even those who regularly get the medicines do not take them and end up developing drug resistance,” he said.

A senior TANSACS official said the organisation’s effort at digitising ART programme was still in preliminary stages.

“We were collecting fingerprints as the idea was to make ART an online process. It would enable the registered patients to receive drugs wherever they are by simply providing their fingerprints. We did not capture their image. We wanted to ensure that there were no dropouts and if we lost some patients we would be able to bring them back to receive treatment,” the official said.

According to him confidentiality of the patients would be maintained. “Anyway this is only an experiment and we have not taken it forward yet,” the official said.
title: TANSACS’ move to digitise ART services raises fears
